item.title: Italy Inflation Unexpectedly Holds Steady Below 2% ECB Goal
item.description: Italian inflation unexpectedly stayed unchanged in June, holding below the European Central Bank’s 2% target for a second month.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

item.title: China Sticks to Stainless-Steel Levies Despite Indonesia Pain
item.description: China will press on with levy anti-dumping duties on imports of stainless-steel products, including from Indonesia, as it seeks to protect a domestic industry battered by persistent oversupply and trade uncertainty.
item.dc:creator: Alfred Cang

item.title: South Africa’s Kganyago Bolsters Case for Lower Inflation Target
item.description: South African Reserve Bank Governor Lesetja Kganyago reinforced his argument for adopting a lower inflation target, noting that the current goal hurts the rand and allows prices to march higher.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: Street vendors in Pretoria, South Africa. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB Fine-Tunes Strategy to World Delivering More Frequent Shocks
item.description: The European Central Bank unveiled tweaks to how it uses monetary policy to steer the economy, reflecting on the recent spike in inflation and anticipating that such shocks are likely to occur more often in the future.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Jana Randow

item.title: Swedish Retail Sales Drop Pressures Riksbank to Cut Again
item.description: Swedish retail sales fell the most in more than three decades last month, continuing a run of disappointing data and increasing pressure on the country’s central bank to lower rates again.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Stockholm. Photographer: Erik Flyg/Bloomberg

item.title: UK’s G7-Topping Growth Confirmed Before Tax and Tariffs Hit
item.description: The UK economy grew strongly in the first quarter of the year, official data confirmed Monday, as Britons spent more and saved less before the Labour government’s tax hikes and extra US tariffs came into effect.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: An employee works in the bonnet area of an Aston Martin DBX SUV.

item.title: US Profit Margins Face Key Risk From Tariffs, Goldman Strategists Say
item.description: US profit margins face a big test in the upcoming reporting season as investors assess the damage from President Donald Trump’s trade war, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. strategists.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: General Mills shares fell 5% last week as the food company warned of a tariff hit on its cost of goods sold.

item.title: South Korea Says US Trade Talks Need to Continue Past Next Week
item.description: South Korea sees the need for trade negotiations with the US to continue past next week’s deadline as Seoul continues to seek exemptions from US tariffs including duties affecting the auto and steel industries.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: South Korean Trade Minister Yeo Han-koo

item.title: Trump Says ‘Mr Japan’ Unfair on Cars, Floats Keeping 25% Tariff
item.description: US President Donald Trump floated the idea of keeping 25% tariffs on Japan’s cars as talks between the two nations continued with little more than a week to go before a slew of higher duties are set to kick in if a trade deal isn’t reached.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

item.title: SNB Stayed Out of FX Market as Franc Slumped in First Quarter
item.description: The Swiss National Bank continued to refrain from steering the franc at the beginning of the year, largely staying out of currency markets for a fifth consecutive quarter while the currency lost value against the euro.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright

item.title: China’s Stimulus Outlook Clouded by Surprise Economic Strength
item.description: China’s economy surprised with signs of improvement even as deflationary pressures persisted and employment weakened, throwing fresh doubt over the likelihood of further monetary stimulus by Beijing in the face of higher US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Yujing Liu

media:content.media:description: Workers on the production line at a toy factory in Shenzhen, China.

item.title: Lower UK-US Car Tariffs Take Effect, Without Progress on Steel
item.description: UK car manufacturers can export to the US under a 10% tariff starting Monday, a reduction from the 25% rate imposed by Donald Trump on other countries, as the first elements of an economic agreement between the US president and Prime Minister Keir Starmer come into effect.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham

item.title: Taiwan Says It Made Constructive Progress in US Trade Talks
item.description: Taiwan said it’s made “constructive progress” in a second round of trade talks with the US, which are aimed at avoiding tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: John Liu

item.title: New Zealand Filled Jobs Decline Adds to Signs of Soft GDP Growth
item.description: New Zealand filled jobs are down to levels last seen in early 2023 as global uncertainty makes employers cautious about hiring.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Withers

item.title: Japan’s Factory Output Misses Expectations as US Tariffs Hit
item.description: Japan’s factory output rose less than expected in May, missing analysts’ estimates as US tariffs hit the nation’s exports, clouding the outlook for the Asian economy as it faces the risk of a technical recession.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

item.title: RBA Should Abandon New 2.5% Inflation Goal, TCorp’s Redican Says
item.description: Australia’s central bank should ditch a new goal of hitting the midpoint of its 2-3% inflation band as the benchmark imposes unrealistic expectations on policymakers, according to Brian Redican, chief economist at sovereign investment manager TCorp.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Saudi FDI Inflows Signal Momentum in Push For Foreign Cash
item.description: Saudi Arabia saw its strongest start to a year for foreign direct investment since 2022, in an early signal the kingdom is gaining some traction in its push to attract overseas capital to support its economic ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Yassmin Jabri

media:content.media:description: Tower cranes at a construction site in the King Abdullah Financial District in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, on Sunday, Dec. 1, 2024. Riyadh’s long-awaited metro system opens as the kingdom pushes ahead with plans to modernize the capital and ease the heavy traffic that has become a commonplace complaint in the city.

item.title: Powell and Lagarde Count Cost of Trump’s Turbulence
item.description: The global economy’s concussion from five months of Donald Trump’s presidency is likely to feature when five of the world’s leading central bank chiefs discuss monetary policy in public on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell (L), Chair of the US Federal Reserve, speaks with Christine Lagarde (R), President of the European Central Bank during the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada, on May 20, 2025. Top finance leaders from the G7 nations gather in Canada starting Tuesday, with concerns including war in Ukraine at the fore while the advanced economies grapple with fallout from US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs. (Photo by Cole Burston/ / AFP) (Photo by COLE BURSTON//AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Indian Negotiators Extend US Stay as Trade Talks Gather Pace
item.description: India’s trade team has extended its stay in Washington to iron out differences as the two sides look to clinch a deal before a July 9 deadline when higher US tariffs are set to kick in, people familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Srivastava

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers stacked on a container ship at Adani Ports and Special Economic Zone Ltd. in Mundra, Gujarat, India, on Saturday, May 18, 2024. With a total market capitalization of $213 billion across 10 listed units alone, Adani Group controls vast swathes of the infrastructure that powers the nation’s growth and underpins the Asian expansion of companies from Apple Inc. to Amazon.com Inc.

item.title: Tariffs Threaten Fed With Real Inflation Headache, BIS Says
item.description: Resurgent US inflation could unfold as the world economy reels from Donald Trump’s disruptive trade policies, the Bank for International Settlements warned.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: Shoppers carry bags in the Chinatown neighborhood of San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. The Bureau of Economic Analysis is scheduled to release personal consumption figures on June 27.

item.title: France Confident Tariff Deal Can Be Reached Before Deadline
item.description: French finance minister Eric Lombard said the European Union can clinch some form of a trade agreement with the US before a July 9 deadline, when Washington is set to impose a 50% tariff on nearly all EU products.
item.dc:creator: Claudia Cohen

item.title: Measures to Ease Inflation Must be Speedy, Says Japan’s Ishiba
item.description: Any measures to ease inflation in Japan must be speedy and shouldn’t impede the government’s ability to fund social services, Japan’s Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said on Sunday, in a comment reflecting his aversion to sales tax cuts as opposition parties campaign to lower the duty ahead of a key election next month.
item.dc:creator: Sakura Murakami

media:content.media:description: Shoppers cross a street in the Ginza district of Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, April 4, 2025. Japan's cabinet office will release a monthly consumer confidence survey on April 9.

item.title: Korea’s Lee Nominates Finance Minister to Tackle Growth, Trade
item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae-myung nominated Koo Yun-cheol as the next finance minister, turning to a veteran bureaucrat to guide the economy at a time of sluggish growth and mounting trade pressures from the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Heesu Lee, Myungshin Cho

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae Myung, South Korea's president, delivers a speech at the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, on Thursday, June 26, 2025. South Korea urgently drafted a supplementary budget to address the "pressing" challenges facing the economy, Lee said. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: China Reiterates Opposition to Any Trade Deals at Its Expense
item.description: China firmly opposes any countries reaching trade agreements with the US that would sacrifice Chinese interests in exchange for tariff relief, according to a statement from the Ministry of Commerce on Saturday night.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Ying Tian

item.title: G-7 Countries Agree to ‘Side by Side’ Tax Deal for US Companies
item.description: The US and fellow Group of Seven nations signed off on an agreement aimed at averting a global tax war, by creating a “side-by-side” system that would exempt US companies from some elements of an existing global agreement.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US secretary of the treasury, speaks to members of the media after a Senate Republican policy luncheon at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Friday, June 27, 2025. President Donald Trump amped up pressure on Congress to speed the passage of his tax-cut bill as Republicans reached a tentative deal on the state and local tax deduction, one of the key sticking points in the negotiations.
